Thus the carbon isotope of inorganic carbonate (
Chinese loess is controlled mainly by two factors: carbon isotopes
of pedogenic carbonate and the proportion of pedogenic
. The vegetation in the western CLP is dominated
by C3 plants and its carbon isotopes varied by ~2
carbon isotopic difference between inorganic carbonate and
organic matter indicates that secondary carbonates roughly
contribute two thirds of the glacial
), which is also attributed to changing vegetation
To determine the climate-vegetation linkage, the
of 20 surface soil samples over the CLP were compared with the
China meteorological data center (Supplementary Fig. 7). The
precipitation is quite similar, whereas its correlation with the
mean annual temperature is much higher than the mean summer
samples and climate variables reveal that while both mean annual
temperature and precipitation can affect vegetation growth, mean
annual summer precipitation likely plays a dominant role in the
vegetation growth over the northwestern CLP. Since temperature
and precipitation are strongly coupled over the CLP (i.e.,
can serve as a sensitive indicator of the monsoon-induced
records display clear precession and millennial
oscillations over the last 140 ka (Fig. 5), identical to those in
Chinese speleothem and Greenland ice-core records
marine isotope stage 5 (MIS 5), three negative peaks in the loess
exhibit a decreasing trend from MIS 5e to MIS 5a,
corresponding to changing summer insolation maxima. Our
Thirteen Heinrich-like events revealed by the loess
match well with weak summer monsoon intervals in the
O and cold stadials in the Greenland ice core.
High similarity between precession-to-millennial variability in
Chinese loess, speleothem, and Greenland ice-core records
record is sensitive to both high-
latitude temperature and low-latitude hydrological changes.
. To estimate the monsoon sensitivity to
various forcings, we use the set of 61 experiments with the climate
, which were designed to sample the ensemble
, and astronomical conditions experienced by the
A statistical model (called emulator) is used to interpolate the
output of these experiments and to simulate the trajectory of the
climate system throughout the Pleistocene. The model results are
used to estimate the relative in
record is affected by changes in mean
annual precipitation (MAP) and temperature (MAT), we focused
on these two variables averaged over northern China (30
120°E), where the precipitation change is more sensitive to
. The emulator is evaluated using a
leave-one-out cross-validation approach, which consists of
predicting the output of one experiment using the emulator
calibrated on all the other experiments. Prediction errors for the
MAT and MAP over northern China are well calibrated, and
about 2/3 of the prediction errors are within one standard
The calibrated emulator is then used for two purposes. First, we
estimated the evolution of these indices throughout the
Pleistocene to reconstruct the MAP and MAT curves. The
MAP and MAT values are the estimated equilibrium response of
HadCM3 for forcing conditions spanning the last 1.7 Ma. The
climate evolution estimated following this approach considers
thus that MAT and MPT are in quasi-equilibrium with
the forcing components, including astronomical solutions
the total variances of both MPT and MAT with the emulator,
before and after the MPT. The expected variances of these
variables caused by the variations of only one or two factors
(eccentricity and longitude of perihelion, obliquity, ice, and CO
were estimated by assuming that the other factors are
indicator of the winter monsoon intensity
display remarkable changes in both frequency and amplitude
On depth scale, dominant cyclicity changes from 5.5 to 6.7 m/cycle below L
The dominant cyclicity on age scale is evidently shifted from 23-kyr before 1.2 Ma (below L
